channel.title: Latest PHMSA Hazardous Materials Incident Reports
channel.description: The latest Form 5800.1 hazardous material reports submitted to the Department of Transportation and posted online by the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration.

item.title: Report X-2023081509
item.description:
Report X-2023081509

Identified by scraper @ 2023-08-30T18:13:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-08-20
  • City: FRENCH CAMP
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNION PACIFIC RAILROAD COMPANY INC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Container HGIU 516245 (load-mixed hazmat) released 0.5 gallons of liquid from the bottom of the container to the ground in the Lathrop yard. 3 out of 12 5-gallon pails of "Zep Morado Super Clean", UN3266 Corrosive Liquid, Basic, Inorganic, N.O.S. (Sodium Thiophosphate) were damaged and released. 1 pail completely released, and the other 2 pails each released 1-gallon, with a total of 7-gallons released. Cause of the release was shifted load and no blocking and bracing.

item.title: Report X-2023081508
item.description:
Report X-2023081508

Identified by scraper @ 2023-08-30T18:13:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-08-16
  • City: LIVONIA
  • State: LA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNION PACIFIC RAILROAD COMPANY INC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: I received a call that there was an odor emitting from a residue Butadiene car in Livonia LA. The car was isolated and discovered that the vapor valve was a quarter turn in the open position with the plug less than tool tight. The valve was closed, and the plug properly tightened, and the odor subsided. No further action was taken and the car release back into transportation.

  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal UPH experienced a : UN1819 Sodium Aluminate release from a 330-gallon poly tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 1-cup of product released impacting a 1' x 1' area of the trailer floor and a 1' x 1' area of the dock floor due to a puncture. The product was transferred from the damaged tote into a new one. Absorbents and neutralizer were deployed to clean the impacted areas. The damaged tote was then cut up and containerized along with all waste into (2) 55-gallon poly drums. All waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. item.title: Report E-2023080346
item.description:
Report E-2023080346

Identified by scraper @ 2023-08-29T21:11:32+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-08-08
  • City: LA SALLE
  • State: IL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XLA experienced a UN2794 Battery, Wet, Filled with Acid release from an 1855-pound battery. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 15-gallons of battery acid released impacting a 4' x 4' area of the concrete bay below the trailer and a 5' x 12' area of the trailer floor. The battery tipped over during dock operations, losing a cell cap. Contractors were able to upright the battery and replace the cap and re-secure it for shipment on. Absorbents and neutralizer were deployed and worked into the impacted areas. The waste was then containerized into a 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2023080340
item.description:
Report E-2023080340

Identified by scraper @ 2023-08-29T21:11:32+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-08-08
  • City: CHEYENNE
  • State: WY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal UWY experienced a UN1993 Unisol Liquid Red BK-50 release from a 275-gallon metal tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 5-gallons of product released impacting a 6' x 1' area of the trailer. The released product impacted the tote body, trailer walls, and floor due to a loose tote cap. Acetone and paint thinner were utilized to try to pull the red color staining off the impacted surfaces to no avail. The crew utilized absorbent pads to collect all free-standing liquid and remove as much staining as possible. The tote was wiped down and the lid was re-secured for shipment on. All impacted absorbents, poly sheeting, and impacted pallet were collected and containerized into (2) 55-gallon metal drums. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2023080562
item.description:
Report E-2023080562

Identified by scraper @ 2023-08-28T18:15:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-08-01
  • City: WALLER
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On August 1, 2023, one (1) 5-gallon pail of paint UN3066 was punctured by a forklift and released approximately three (3) cups to the dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Ambipar to remediate the impacted surfaces. Ambipar personnel deployed granular absorbents to the corrosive paint-related material-impacted dock floor and swept them in with hand tools. All spent absorbents were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum and the one (1) 5-gallon damaged pail was placed in one (1) 55-gallon poly drum for terminal disposal.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: Approx. around 6:15am Hazmat steel drum was found sitting on the belt line damaged. There was a small amount of spilled paint at the top of drum around cap. Steel drum was placed into a red hazardous tote and moved to hazmat cage for inspection. DescribePack: There was a small amount of paint spilled around the top of drum where cap is located. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Steel drum was placed into a red hazardous tote using proper eye and wear gear to transport to hazmat cage for inspection.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: Package was found by a manager at door 124 at KANN-289. Hazmat was brought to QA Hazmat cage for inspection. During the inspection it was found that the cap was broken/missing. The remaining cap was missing and not found inside the packaging. DescribePack: The failure was due to a broken/missing cap on one of the glass bottles. No other caps or bottles were damaged. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Bottles and package were placed into a 20-gallon salvage drum to prevent further leakage.

item.title: Report X-2023080558
item.description:
Report X-2023080558

Identified by scraper @ 2023-08-28T18:15:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-08-01
  • City: BREINIGSVILLE
  • State: PA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: 1. X-2023080558 SequenceEvent: Package was processed and being delivered to Outbounds, Load Area 1. A few minutes later, manager explained to me box was leaking powder. Box was not leaking beforehand. Probable cause of leakage could be mishandling of package by package handler. No damages to outer packaging. Cleaned up area by sweeping up powder substance into the QA bin with the damaged hazmat in bin as well. DescribePack: Lid of Inner packaging was loose and seemed to be the source of leakage. Location of the loose end was the back of the package. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Checked to see if all openings were closed and package was standing upright. 2. X-2023080636 SequenceEvent: Package was found in outbounds by management leaking the substance. DOT hazmat label was located on the package and QA was called. QA contained spill and placed package in hazmat tote. DescribePack: Package had loose lid causing contents to spill out DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Substance was contained and package was placed in hazmat tote

item.title: Report E-2023080323
item.description:
Report E-2023080323

Identified by scraper @ 2023-08-28T18:15:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-08-10
  • City: LA SALLE
  • State: IL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XLA experienced a NA1993 Spec-Aid 8Q123ULS release from a 275-gallon poly tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 1-teaspoon of product released impacting a 5" x 1" area of the tote lid due to being crushed/punctured as a result of improper loading. The material was transferred from the damaged tote into a new one for shipment on. The damaged tote was then cut up and containerized along with cleanup debris into a 55-gallon metal drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.description:
Report E-2023080308

Identified by scraper @ 2023-08-28T18:15:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-08-04
  • City: INDEPENDENCE
  • State: MO
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: CLEAN HARBORS ENVIRONMENTAL SERVICES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: When unloading at the facility it was noticed that the floor around the tote was wet. They immediately put down absorbent material to collect the material. Tote was removed from truck and our inhouse response team arrived to transfer the material to a new tote. It was discovered that a small pinhole was in the top of the tote and the material would seep out. There was less than 0.5 gallons released and was all contained in truck no material made it out of the vehicle. The cleanup process was completed while wearing the proper PPE and all material was packaged and processed in the proper manner.

item.title: Report E-2023080247
item.description:
Report E-2023080247

Identified by scraper @ 2023-08-28T18:15:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-08-08
  • City: GLENPOOL
  • State: OK
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal LTU experienced a UN1789 Blue Whale Muriatic Acid release from 2 boxes, each containing (4) 1-gallon poly jugs. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 1-gallon of product released impacting a 1' x 1' area of the concrete dock floor due to the product falling as a result of improper loading. The impacted area was neutralized with soda ash and then cleaned with granular absorbents. All cleanup debris and neutralized cardboard were placed into a 55-gallon poly drum. The (8) 1-gallon bottles of damaged leaking product were placed into an additional 55-gallon poly drum. All waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

Report E-2023080193

Identified by scraper @ 2023-08-24T18:13:50+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-08-07
  • City: DECATUR
  • State: AL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal NDE experienced a UN1263 Cycon UV-HighGloss Monolyer 757-4F release from a 5-gallon steel pail due to improper loading. XPO terminal personnel donned PPE and contained and cleaned the release with granular absorbents. The damaged pail and cleanup debris were collected and containerized into a 55-gallon metal drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2023080172
item.description:
Report E-2023080172

Identified by scraper @ 2023-08-24T18:13:50+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-08-04
  • City: BLYTHE
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal UBY experienced a UN2680 Lithium Hydroxide Monohydrate release from (2) 50-pound poly bags. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 1-cup of product released impacting a 1' x 1' area of the trailer floor due to improper loading. The damaged bags and released product were collected into a 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2023080170
item.description:
Report E-2023080170

Identified by scraper @ 2023-08-24T18:13:50+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-08-04
  • City: BRAINTREE
  • State: MA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XEE experienced a UN1993 Unisol Liquid Red BK-50 release from a 300-gallon metal tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 1-gallon of product released impacting a 5' x 5' area of the trailer floor due to a bad weld on the tote. Contractors transferred the product from the damaged tote into a new 275-gallon poly tote and 55-gallon metal drum. Absorbents were deployed and worked into the impacted area. All waste was collected into a separate 55-gallon metal drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2023080163
item.description:
Report E-2023080163

Identified by scraper @ 2023-08-24T18:13:50+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-08-04
  • City: LOUISVILLE
  • State: KY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XLU experienced a customer location release of UN1090 Acetone from a box containing (4) 1-gallon metal cans. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup. Contractors arrived onsite and located one cardboard box of LAPALM Acetone that was slightly wet with residual Acetone. There were no wet spots or residual product on the trailer floor. The XPO driver had already separated the damaged box and delivered the rest of the load to the customer. Contractors placed the box into a 55-gallon metal drum which was then transported back to XPO terminal XLU located in Louisville, KY and staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2023080146
item.description:

  • City: NORTH HUNTINGDON

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XPB experienced a UN1993 Tyzor IAM release from a 55-gallon metal drum. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 2-gallons of product released impacting a 5' x 5' area of the concrete dock floor and an 8' x 1' area of the trailer floor due to a pinhole puncture. Oil dri and simple green were utilized to clean the impacted areas and then collected into a 55-gallon metal drum. The damaged drum was placed into an 85-gallon metal overpack. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: Customers Power Bank started smoking on board Flight 4521 prior to the flight departing the gate. The Customer gave the power bank to the Provo Agent. The Provo Agent took the Power Bank to the top of the Jetway and gave it to the Operation Agent. The power bank was no longer smoking, so Airport Operations advised SWA to dispose of item. OAK Maintenance came to get item to place in a fire containment bag, per SWA Safety and Security.

  • Description: Arlie Fears, FRA Inspector, found UTLX 208142 releasing Diesel Fuel in the Green River, Wy yard. Pacific West, contractor, responded and found two swing bolts on the manway less than tool tight resulting in the release of approximately one quart of diesel Fuel. item.title: Report E-2023080485
item.description:
Report E-2023080485

Identified by scraper @ 2023-08-30T18:13:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-07-28
  • City: EAST SAINT LOUIS
  • State: IL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On July 28, 2023, one (1) 250-gallon tote of UN3266 leaked approximately ten (10) gallons of product due to a faulty valve. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from ES+ to remediate the impacted site. ES+ personnel deployed granular absorbents and a neutralizing agent to the impacted trailer and pavement and swept them in with hand tools. All spent absorbents were collected and containerized into two (2) 55-gallon drums. Crews transferred the product from the 330-gallon tote into one (1) 250-gallon tote and two (2) 55-gallon drums.

item.title: Report E-2023080481
item.description:

  • City: ARLINGTON
  • State: TN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On July 28, 2023, one (1) 1-gallon bottle of sodium hydroxide was damaged and released all its contents to the dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from E3 to assess the release. E3 contained the remaining product in one (1) 55-gallon drum for consolidation. The crew deployed absorbents and neutralized the released material. All impacted absorbents, debris, and PPE were contained in a separate 55-gallon drum. Both drums were labeled and staged onsite to be profiled and disposed of by R+L.

The contents were 20 small cylinders of refrigerant gas, each having a 2.2 label on the outside. There were no marks or labels on the outside package indicating the contents were dangerous goods. After reaching out to the shipper and manufacturer a Safety Data Sheet could not be located. UN1956 Compressed Gas, n.o.s. 2.2 was selected for the purposes of this report. If the SDS is provided by the shipper or manufacturer an updated 5800 will be provided. The shipment is being held pending disposition.

  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Carrier/Reporter: CSX TRANSPORTATION, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On 7/25/2023, personnel at the CSX Queensgate Yard in Cincinnati, OH, reported AXZZ 32036, a loaded tank car of Xylene Ethylbenzene (ALOX), was observed leaking from the top of the car. The car was isolated and the shipper, Kraton Chemicals, was notified via CHEMTREC (report #2023-07-25-00327). James Courtney, a CSXT hazardous materials manager, was dispatched to the scene and found (2) of (6) manway cover bolts less than tool tight. The manway bolts were tightened to secure the car for movement inside the yard. The issue was identified and corrective actions were communicated to Kraton Chemicals representative: Gerri Sage (904-316-3655, Gerri.Sage@Kraton.com). Prior to releasing the car into transportation, HEPACO, a CSX response contractor, cleaned the impacted surfaces on the top and sides of the car, inspected the manway gasket, re-secured all manway cover bolts tool tight, and applied manway custody seal #000102. Delay in 5800.1 submission due to online portal not accepting submission.

item.title: Report E-2023070957
item.description:
Report E-2023070957

Identified by scraper @ 2023-08-29T21:11:32+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-07-25
  • City: RUSSELL
  • State: KY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: CSX TRANSPORTATION, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On 7/25/2023, at approximately 1650 hours, personnel in the CSX Russell, KY Yard reported a suspect Non-Accident Release involving PROX17502, a loaded tank car ofUN1830, Sulfuric Acid- reported to have product leaking from the top. The car was isolated and the shipper, Norflaco Sales Glencore Canada, was notified via CHEMTREC (report #2023-07-25-00337). Quick Response, a CSXT emergency response contractor, was dispatched to the scene and found the vapor line valve in the fully open position and the secondary closure plug not installed. The issue identified and corrective actions were communicated to the shipper’s representative- Marie-France Rollin (1-450-567-2026, Marie-France.Rollin@glencore.ca). Contractor personnel closed the valve with the valve handle and installed the secondary closure plug tool tight. Contractor personnel then performed neutralization and decontamination of the impacted surfaces on the exterior top and sides of the tank car. The car was placed on hold in the yard pending final inspection by CSX Hazmat personnel. On 7/27/23 PROX17502 was inspected by CSX personnel and released for transportation.

The car was isolated and the shipper Marathon, was notified via CHEMTREC (report 2023-0727-00103). HEPACO, a CSXT emergency response contractor, was dispatched to the scene and found the liquid line valve partially closed and the secondary closure plug less than tool tight. The issue was identified and corrective actions were communicated to the shipper’s emergency contact: Michael Murray (606-922-4079). Contractor personnel closed the angle valve and secured the secondary closure. The leak was secured and the car was released for transport.

item.title: Report E-2023070882
item.description:
Report E-2023070882

Identified by scraper @ 2023-08-29T21:11:32+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-07-14
  • City: EAST SAINT LOUIS
  • State: IL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: CSX INTERMODAL TERMINALS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On 07/14/23 at 1912hrs personnel with CSX Intermodal East St Louis, ILL Terminal discovered APHU659439, a freight container of "Freight All Kinds" with interior explosion and fire. The Fairmont City, IL fire department responded and extinguished the fire- no injuries were reported and no waterways impacted. Upon opening of the container, it was determined the lading included a hazardous commodity that was not described on the shipper's bill-of-lading; (UN3480, Lithium-Ion Batteries, Class 9, PG II). There were no indications of a hazardous material shipment on shipper's bill-of-lading or the freight container. CSXT emergency response contractor, ENVIROSERVE, was dispatched to the scene for cleanup after scene was released by the fire dept. The response contractor decontaminated all impacted areas and separated damaged lading into one roll-off unit. All damaged freight was transported to the customer’s facility for further handling. In addition to the shipment containing an undeclared hazardous materials, the cause of the fire/explsoin was due to inadequate blocking and bracing of the lading inside the container. This allowed the lading to rub against itself, creating arc-friction, resulting in an explosion with fire. The rail shipper, CMA-CGM America LLC, representative was notified by CSXI Customer Service, Case 672321. The Illinois EMA was notified, report# H-2023-0587.

It was seen that during travel, a small hole developed on the bottom of one of the drums allowing for an estimated 3L of product to escape. It is not known when or how the hole developed. item.title: Report X-2023080537
item.description:
Report X-2023080537

Identified by scraper @ 2023-08-28T18:15:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-07-31
  • City: LEWISTON
  • State: ME
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: The package was discovered during the unload sorting process at this station in the morning. the item was brought to the QA dept for further inspection. The outer package had no labels indicating haxardous materials were inside the package. An admin begun the normal inspection while lifting and handling the package and observed their was an inner package with corrosive labels. Immediately the Admin placed the item down and noticed her feet were beginning to feel a "burning sensation." Another admin quickly placed appropriate PPE on and read the label for first aid instructions. A SDS was printed and the admin took measures to wash and the area and seek medical attention along with a manager who completed an incident report. The package was then processed approprately as a hazmat and the containment mitigated and processed. DescribePack: The package was wet and had open closures. Upon inspection the outer package was retaped and the inner package had labels indicating it was corrosive materials inside. The label itself was undeclared. There were 4 gallon plastic jugs of cleanser/degreaser. One jug was missing a cap causing it to leak throughout the package and had noticeably less quantity in the jug. The liquid had saturated the other 3 bottles in the package. DurationRel: 2 and MitigateEffect: Once Identified as a hazmat the item was placed in a hazmat tote. The process of paperwork was immediately handled. The first aid practice for the substance was printed and the Admin quickly began first aid measures and sought medical attention.

  • Description: On July 28, 2023, one (1) 5-gallon pail of printer ink (UN1210) was damaged during transit and released approximately three (3) gallons of product to the trailer interior and dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Environmental Works, Inc. (EWI) to remediate the impacted surfaces. The EWI crew identified the damaged pail and contained it in one (1) 55-gallon drum. The crew deployed absorbents and degreaser to the material and utilized hand tools to collect the impacted solids. All additional waste was contained in the same 55-gallon drum for disposal by R+L.

FCE personnel deployed absorbents to the impacted tote and trailer and swept them in using hand tools. All spent absorbents were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum that RLC personnel took possession of to add to the facility waste stream

item.title: Report E-2023080326
item.description:
Report E-2023080326

Identified by scraper @ 2023-08-28T18:15:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-07-26
  • City: DALLAS
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On July 26, 2023, one (1) 5-gallon pail of UN1760 was crushed during transit and released approximately three (3) gallons of product to the trailer floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Lone Star Hazmat (LSH) to remediate the impacted surface. Crews deployed a neutralizing agent to the impacted area. Once neutralization was confirmed with pH strips, crews deployed granular absorbents to the impacted area and worked them in with hand tools. The undamaged cargo was wiped down and repalletized for continued processing and shipping. All UN1760 impacted materials and spent absorbents were collected and containerized into two (2) 55-gallon drums for disposal.

  • Incident Date: 2023-07-12
  • City: GREENCASTLE

  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XHG experienced a UN1789 J.T. Baker Hydrochloric Acid, SN Volumetric Solution release from (2) 5-gallon poly jugs. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 1-gallon of product released impacting a 5' x 6" area of the trailer floor due to punctures caused by a load shift. Lye was utilized to neutralize the impacted area and absorbents were deployed and worked in to collect all liquid. The damaged jug and cleanup debris were collected and containerized into a 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2023080256

  • Description: On July 25, 2023, one (1) 55-gallon drum of resin solution was punctured and released approximately less than one (<1) gallon of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from HazChem Environmental (HCE) to remediate the impacted surfaces. HCE personnel deployed granular absorbents to the resin solution-impacted trailer interior and swept them in with hand tools. All spent absorbents and damaged drum were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum and one (1) 85-gallon over-pack for terminal disposal.

item.title: Report E-2023080255
item.description:
Report E-2023080255

Identified by scraper @ 2023-08-28T18:15:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-07-24
  • City: KENNESAW
  • State: GA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On July 24, 2023, three (3) 55-gallon drums of sodium chlorite were damaged and released approximately five (5) gallons of product to the dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Hull's Environmental Services (HES) to remediate the site. The crew identified the pallet of damaged drums and secured the drums in three (3) 95-gallon overpack drums. HES deployed granular absorbents to the dock floor and worked them in with hand tools. All clean up debris and PPE were contained in one (1) 55-gallon drum.

item.title: Report E-2023080253
item.description:
Report E-2023080253

Identified by scraper @ 2023-08-28T18:15:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-07-21
  • City: WILMINGTON
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On July 21, 2023, ten (10) 1-gallon pails of paint were crushed and released approximately one-half (0.5) gallon of product to the pallet on the dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Thin Line Environmental (TLE) to remediate the impacted surfaces. TLE personnel utilized absorbent pads and a degreasing solution to wipe down any impacted freight. Crews cut up the impacted pallet with hand tools and took it for waste. TLE personnel restacked and rewrapped the remediated freight for further shipment. All used absorbent pads, the cut-up pallet, the ten (10) damaged pails, and any miscellaneous waste were collected and containerized into three (3) 55-gallon metal drums.

  • City: GARLAND
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal LGT experienced a UN1789 Blue Whale Muriatic Acid release from boxed containing (4) 1-gallon poly jugs. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 1-gallon of product released to a 1' x 1' area of the dock floor due to a forklift puncture. Several other jugs appeared to also have loose caps, saturating their boxes. A total of 5 boxes of bottles were found damaged and impacted or releasing. The impacted dock area was neutralized with sodium bicarb. All jugs were placed into a 55-gallon poly drum. The impacted cardboard, absorbents and cleanup debris were placed into a separate 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.description:
Report X-2023080478

Identified by scraper @ 2023-08-24T18:13:50+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-07-25
  • City: EDINBURG
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: Package was inbound scan at 0412 on 7/25/2023 at Edin 0785 and placed under the rollers at unload door 6 since it was a misloaded package. At 0700 QA was working on packages in the unload and came across the Item. Outer packaging looked wet damaged, so contents were inspected. Upon inspection it was found that 1 of the inner items had a leak. Package was placed in a yellow salvage drum and secured at QA1 to be processed post sort. DescribePack: Outer package appears wet damaged at the bottom one third / base of the package at one side. Tape closing/securing the bottom of the package is only covering 1/4 of the closure. only 1 of the 4 inner containers appears to be undamaged. 2 items appear dented at their base but have no leak. One inner container is crushed/dented at its base and has leaked over 1/2 of its contents. DurationRel: 3 and MitigateEffect: As soon as QA found the package inspection was performed to identify the cause of the wet damage on the outer packaging. When it was found to be caused by the inner contents of the package, item was secured and placed in a yellow salvaged drum and taken to QA1.

item.title: Report E-2023080131
item.description:
Report E-2023080131

Identified by scraper @ 2023-08-24T18:13:50+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-07-19
  • City: GRAND VIEW
  • State: ID
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On July 19, 2023, one (1) 55-gallon drum containing sodium carbonate was damaged during transit and released approximately ten (10) gallons of product to the trailer floor and asphalt roadway as well as the soil/gravel shoulder. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from The L&R Group (TLR) to remediate the impacted surfaces. Crews placed the damaged 50-gallon drum in an 85-gallon over pack drum for disposal. TLR personnel deployed granular absorbents to the impacted trailer floor and asphalt and worked them in with hand tools. Crews utilized hand tools to collect the absorbents and impacted soil and gravel from the shoulder and placed in a 30-gallon drum for disposal. All sodium carbonate impacted material was containerized in one (1) 85-gallon drum and one (1) 30-gallon drum and sent with the truck to the Boise, ID RLC terminal.

  • Description: Trailer had been dropped in drop lot for delivery on Monday 7/31/23 when facility personnel went to retrieve trailer to be unloaded they noticed the spillage under trailer. Containment was set up and trailer was immediately unloaded to get to leaking container. The container was packed in a salvage drum and all contents were cleaned up using the proper PPE and absorbents then deposed of in the proper manner. The gravel under trailer was excavated and disposed of accordingly the new gravel was put back. The spill did not pose a threat to human life or waterways. The failure of the container was determined to be a crack in the bottom of the plastic drum.

item.title: Report I-2023070016
item.description:

  • City: ESCONDIDO
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Carrier/Reporter: INGENIUM GROUP, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Waste material was staged onto a pallet with other materials then loaded onto an lngenium truck at the customer's facility. The shipment was then routed through the lngenium - Santa Clara transfer facility, then to the lngenium - Escondido transfer facility. Upon arrival, lngenium - Escondido operations began unloading the shipment from the trailer with a forklift. The pallet with the container in question come into contact with a protruding piece of aluminum siding. The container sustained a 5 to 6 inch gash near the bottom and immediately drained onto the trailer floor. The material began leaking onto the loading dock pavement when a second employee noticed and notified the forklift driver. The forklift driver placed the pallet down and backed the forklift out of the trailer. The driver donned his respirator, grabbed absorbent, and began covering the release. The second employee notified the manager. The material was contained before spreading from beneath the trailer. The used absorbent was removed and drummed for disposal.

  • Description: On 6/23/23 at 12:30 am, a ground package coming out of door 37 caught on fire while on the sort aisle conveyor belt. One of the aerosol cans in the package leaked and caught fire. The fire dept was called at 12:31 am and 225 employees were evacuated from the building. The fire was then extinguished by the Base mechanic and Sort Supervisor. At approximately 12:58 am the fire dept gave all clear to go back insidethe building and the sort operation started again after belt cleanup at 1:17 am.

  • Carrier/Reporter: DELTA AIR LINES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: At DTW, on 6/30/23, a Cargo agent loaded a Dangerous Goods(DG) shipment(UN3082) into the back of a SEMI truck. A second agent was following behind, driving a forklift, with a different shipment. The second agent's forklift tines were sticking out on the other side of the freight and punctured a hole in the DG shipment. The agent pulled the forklift out of the truck tracking the DG into the warehouse. The DG was contained, and the Cargo agent(s) followed instructions detailed in the Emergency Response Guide book. The domestic area was evacuated (employees) for approximately seven hours. Clean Harbor(spill business partner) was contacted and arrived four hours later due to no available cleaning crews in the area. The Airport Authority and the Fire Department determined there was no immediate threat; however, they instructed the team to keep everyone out of the affected area until the spill was cleaned. The cleaning operation completed at 2320.

The shipment was accepted and flown to Dublin on Aer Lingus flight EI122/24Jun. Upon arrival in Dublin, the shipment was investigated and found to have incorrect markings indicating the consignment actually contained fully regulated Lithium Batteries contained in equipment that had not been properly declared. The shipper provided an updated AWB and shippers declaration for the cargo after it had already been flown from Chicago from Dublin.

After completing a full inventory of the package a travelling veterinarian who was attempting to move his equipment from Texas to Montana following a procedure included a plastic one gallon jug of isopropyl alcohol. The other three packages in the shipment were not identified and are assumed to have moved to their final destination. Package is being held pending FAA investigation

  • Description: Part of a 5 piece multi piece shipment, this package was offered to the spill office at our Memphis hub location. Package consisted of a fibreboard box containing a metal can of UN 1263. Brown paper was used for dunnage. There was no positive closure nor moisture barrier reported with the package. Metal can inside was dented under top rim of can, however, there was no damage to outside box correlating to damage on can. Cause of damage is unknown, however allowed for top of cam to come loose and allow for an estimated 2.5 liters to leak. Escaped paint then leaked on remaining 4 packages. All cans were placed in a steel salvage container and shipper was contacted for an amended shipper's declaration for continued travel.

As he crossed over a bridge he noticed material white in color coming out of the back of the truck (270). O'Brien pulled over immediately to check out the truck upon doing so noticed there was emulsion flowing out from what appeared to be several places. O'Brien immediately called his supervisor Derrick Paro who instructed him to call PERS and also NY DEC was notified. O'Brien was told by PERS that appropriate personnel would be dispatched for cleanup. The site was cleaned up and there is nothing further at this time.

  • City: LAURENS

  • Carrier/Reporter: FREEHOLD CARTAGE INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Driver and technician were transferring drum from pallet onto trailer floor when it suddenly cracked, causing contents of drum to spill out. The liquid spilled onto concrete and trace amounts impacted storm drain. Generator responded immediately to mitigate spill and potential environmental cleanup. Pigs were placed around storm drain which prevented most of the liquid from entering storm drain which helped isolate further cleanup and liquid run off. Acid absorbent material and lime were used to soak up remaining liquid. The PPE and contents of cleanup were placed in over-pack drum and transported to TSDF as required. After inspection grounds it was determined no liquid was visibility detected in outfall nor did it impact round soil. Under the advisement from South Carolina Department of Health and Enviromental (SCDHEC) lime was dispensed into storm drain as added precaution. In addition, quarterly storm-water was recommended to assure no further contamination occurred.

item.title: Report I-2023060096
item.description:
Report I-2023060096

Identified by scraper @ 2023-08-31T00:31:52+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-05-15
  • City: PORT ARTHUR
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: THE KANSAS CITY SOUTHERN RAILWAY COMPANY
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: At 17:50 on 5/15/2023 a Kansas City Southern Railway OBA CPKCR employee working in the CPKCR Port Arthur rail yard reported that loaded tank car GATX 7520 (Sulfuric Acid) was leaking from the top of the car. The CPKCR Hazmat Department mobilized a railroad qualified response contractor to assess and mitigate the release. Upon arrival, GATX 7520 was inspected by the response contractor and discovered to be leaking from beneath the liquid line fill cap. The vapor line valve end cap was removed and the valve opened to relieve any internal pressure that was present. Once this was done, the leak stopped. The liquid line fill cap was removed and inspected, revealing that the internal gasket was deteriorated. A temporary repair was completed by responders to seal the closure until the following day. The vapor valve and end cap were secured tool tight, and the liquid fill line cap was replaced and secured tool tight. The car was moved to the RIP track and arrangements were made with the shipper to procure a new fill cap gasket. On 5/16/2023 a new gasket was provided by the shipper, and responders, once again, released any internal pressure by opening the vapor line valve end cap and vapor valve. The liquid fill line cap was removed and the new gasket installed. The liquid fill line cap was reinstalled and rendered tool tight. The vapor valve was placed in the closed position and the end plug was also rendered tool tight. Total estimated release was 15 gallons. File Note: Item 19-the quantity released was estimated based on the best information available at the time of filing. This shipment was offered as a 'bulk' shipment, aka one car load, therefore the exact amount offered in this package is not known to the carrier. This carrier does not have access to mass balance data which can exactly quantify this value.

  • City: MANSFIELD

  • Carrier/Reporter: BUCKLEY OIL COMPANY
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Driver noticed minimal leakage and immediately exited the highway and pulled over away from traffic. Driver called Buckley Oil Company Headquarters and personnel were dispatched to assist. Upon arrival, EH&S and Sales Manager discovered a small amount of product had leaked from a tote and was dripping from the back of the vehicle. Cause of the leak was a damaged Polyethylene Tote leaking product as the vehicle moved. Once the vehicle was stopped, product stopped leaking from the tote. Absorbent pads were used to soak up product from the vehicle to prevent any further dripping onto the ground. Absorbent pads, duct tape and plastic wrap were used to temporarily repair the tote so it could be transported back to Buckley Oil Headquarters for disposal. Oil absorbent was used on the pavement where the product had dripped. Additionally, a small amount of grass and dirt were removed where product had splashed off of the pavement. Photos of the scene are available if necessary.

item.title: Report I-2023060015
item.description:
Report I-2023060015

Identified by scraper @ 2023-08-30T00:33:49+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-05-03
  • City: DENVER
  • State: CO
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED AIRLINES HOLDINGS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: During mid flight a passenger in 35E pulled me aside and mentioned her battery pack was over heating. I immediately contacted the purser to inform her we had a battery pack over heating in the back and I was going to use the TCB protocol. The purser came back and also confirmed the battery was over heating and we proceeded to isolate the battery back in the TCB. Purser notified pilot and TCB was locked in the Right Aft Lavatory. Bag was handed over to agent in Denver. Mid flight, I received a call from FA in the back (ebheer) that a passenger (seated in 35e, Mrs Dixon) informed him that her battery (the battery wasn't even being used) for an inflatable pillow was overheating and he decided to use the TCB bag to prevent anything further. I went to the back to check it out and it was indeed very warm, so I backed his decision and also advised the pilots of the situation. He took the steps necessary to lock the battery in the aft lav. Upon arrival, the bag was handed off to the csr. The FA TCB was used for a baby device battery that started to overheat and smell like it was burning. No further issues. Write up was done and Mx replaced the bag.

item.title: Report I-2023060049
item.description:
Report I-2023060049

  • Incident Date: 2023-04-25
  • City: ZILLAH
  • State: WA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: WILBUR-ELLIS COMPANY
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: According to the information obtained, the following occurred. While at intersection, a leak was detected from tote, coming from back of truck bed. Free product released to the asphalt roadway and adjacent soil. GrayMar Environmental was dispatched to perform the cleanup. Washington Department of Ecology responded to assess and monitor response. Upon inspection, one 330-gallon tote was discovered cracked, which resulted in the release of approximately 130 gallons of product. GrayMar Environmental proceeded to transfer the remaining product into a recovery tote to prevent further release. GrayMar Environmental used absorbent material on the asphalt roadway and hand shoveled grossly contaminated soil into a stockpile, which was covered with poly, pending return for excavation. GrayMar Environmental returned the following day, excavated contaminated soil, and used a street sweeper to clear residual off the roadway. Disposal was coordinated in accordance with local, state, and federal regulations. There were no injuries or exposures.

  • Description: The vehicle was in transit and ran over road debris, resulting in damage to the steering system of the road tractor. The driver lost control and collided with bridge support post. After the collision, the road tractor caught fire resulting in destruction of the road tractor and damage to the tank trailer, A release of material from the tanker did not occur. Environmental cleanup activities involved product transfer from the damaged tanker to a new tanker, clean up of debris, and abatement of a minor motor oil and diesel fuel release from the road tractor of the vehicle. After the fire was extinguished, the product in the tanker was transferred to another tanker. The damaged tanker was trailer #1057.
